Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The

• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an

Additional Findings Yes
Three separate complaints were received related to the above referenced allegations.
All licensing related allegations will be addressed in this report. I reviewed each
complaint. The first complaint was received on 6/29/2022 alleging the first eight
allegations and denoting that the youth is placed in a dangerous neighborhood. The
latter of which I did not assess in this complaint because the youth was placed into this
Flint, Michigan independent living home by DHHS and the safety of the neighborhood
appropriateness of the placement was determined by DHHS. A second complaint was
received on 7/12/2022, repeating the allegation pertaining to the PPO/transportation
and racial slur allegations. This second complaint also alleged the medical passport,
FTM and prevention of a visit with Youth 1 allegations. A third complaint was received
on 7/12/2022 that alleged the last three allegations listed above related to checks being
withheld, Youth 1 having a broken window in her room: and the home’s lack of security
protocol for visitors.

ALLEGATION:
Youth 1 is not being given her medication two days out of the week due to it being
locked up.
INVESTIGATION:
Complainant X
On 6/30/2022 I spoke with the complainant, Complainant X by telephone.
Complainant X confirmed the allegation in the complaint. Complainant X reported
4

Youth 1’s medication is for GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease) and one of
her medication is Prilosec. Complainant X reported notwithstanding the agency’s
reports of keeping all medication locked, this is an independent living program and
Youth 1 wants to keep her medication in her room. Complainant X said there was a
family team meeting recently and this issue was brought up, but Case Manager E
will not do anything about it.
Independent Living Director B
On 7/5/2022, and 7/18/2022 I spoke with Independent Living (IL) Director B by
telephone regarding this allegation. IL Director B also reported information about this
allegation during an onsite visit on 7/28/2022. IL Director B advised that youths are
responsible for taking their own medications. He also advised that medication is kept
locked in the office for all youths; the staff alerts the youth of the medication time and
then gives it to the youth. The medication is not dispensed, but rather given to the
youth to take. He reported following an incident in the past where a youth tried to
overdose on her psychotropic medication, the agency started locking all youths’
medications up as a safety precaution. He acknowledged keeping all medication
locked is not written in the policy, but it is something they do for protection. He
reported as it relates to Youth 1, staff reported they were trying to wake Youth 1 so
she could take her medication, but Youth 1 refused to get up. He said it was not
clear to staff that they could leave Youth 1’s medication out, so they did not. He
reported there was an FTM around this matter; and during that meeting Case
Manager E reported Youth 1’s refusals to wake up. At that meeting Youth 1’s
attorney/GAL (Guardian Ad Litem) reported the agency would not be held
responsible for Youth 1 refusing if Youth 1 held on to her medication. Therefore, they
have since provided the medication to Youth 1 for her to keep in her room.
Youth and staff interviews:
Youth 1(age 16), Youth 2(age 16), Youth 3(age 16), Staff C, Staff D, Staff F, and
Staff G were interviewed about this allegation. All the staff, as well as, Youth 1, and
Youth 3 (who also reported taking medication for GERD and sleep), affirmed the
information IL Director B reported related to youths’ medication being kept locked.
Neither of these youths, nor the IL workers knew what policy specifically indicates
related to medication storage or administration.
Youth 1
I interviewed, Youth 1 during an onsite IL home visit on 7/6/2022. Youth 1 reported
her medications as Prilosec, and Zyrtec, which she takes twice daily; as well as
MiraLAX for constipation, which is taken as needed. She said all of her medications
are over the counter. She reported getting her medication in the
afternoons/evenings, but not in the morning on Wednesday and Saturday. She
reported having asked Case Manager E to allow her to keep her medications in her
room since her admission to the program; only to be told for safety precaution she
could not. Youth 1 reported, prior to this placement, she was responsible for her
own medication. She reported the midnight staff person is supposed to wake her
before they leave at 7:00am to give her the medication. She reported staff have
5

claimed they tried to wake her, but that is not true because she is a light sleeper.
She admitted there may have been one such occasion. She reported there is no
staff present on Saturday to provide medication.
Youth 2 and Youth 3
Both of these youths were interviewed by me onsite at an IL home visit on 7/6/2022.
Youth 2 reported not being aware of youths’ medications being locked because she
is not on medication. Neither she nor Youth 3 had specific information about this
allegation.
Staff C and Staff D
Staff C and Staff D were interviewed by me onsite at an IL home visit on 7/6/2022.
Staff C is a morning (7:00am-3:00pm) IL worker (except Saturday when she works
second shift- 3:00pm-11:00pm) and Staff D works the second shift. Both of these IL
workers reported the third shift staff, not the afternoon shift, is involved in ensuring
that youths are given their medication for consumption.
Staff C reported Youth 1 told her on more than one occasion in June of 2022 that
staff were not giving her medication on Wednesday and Saturday. Staff C told Youth
1 to talk with Case Manager E. She gave Youth 1 Case Manager E’s and IL Director
B’s telephone number, advising Youth 1 that Staff C could not do anything about this
situation.
Staff D reported that any deviation from their rule, where a youth is allowed to have
their medication in their room, had been done on a case-by-case basis. Staff D
reported not personally experiencing this, but reported hearing that staff were
knocking on Youth 1’s door to wake and give Youth 1 her medications, but Youth 1
would not wake up. Staff D reported seeing that information in their staff daily log
book. Staff D showed me that daily log book for review.
Case Manager E and Staff F
Case Manager E and Staff F were interviewed by me via telephone on 7/13/2022
and 7/21/2022 respectively. This case manager and IL worker, also both reported
what other agency staff persons reported about the agency’s medication protocol of
locking up medication and the reason for it.
Case Manager E reported Youth 1’s GERD medication as being
Omeprazole/Prilosec (20mg twice daily) and Zyrtec (10mg- once daily). The
medication was initially over the counter until she took Youth 1 to get a prescription
on 6/9/2022. As for Youth 1 not getting these medications on Wednesday and
Saturday, or as required, Case Manager E reported what other staff reported about
third shift staff giving the medication to the Youth 1 and reports of Youth 1, at times,
not waking up to take the medication from the staff. Case Manager E acknowledged
not being onsite during those times, and reporting what had been reported to her.
6

Staff F acknowledged being the primary third shift staff (11:00pm-7:00 am). She said
youth medications are usually given out during second shift (3:00pm-11:00pm)
before she arrives. She said the youth is to come and get the medication from the
staff. Staff F reported she only provides youths their medication if the second shift
worker informs her that staff did not do so. On those occasions, Staff F reported she
goes to the youth’s room and tell the youth to come take their medication. Staff F
reported knowing Youth 1 has GERD, but not what medications Youth 1 takes for it.
She reported, she just unlocks the medication cabinet, and the youth grabs the
medication from her. She did not report being aware of Youth 1 missing any
medication doses. She said when she arrives for her shift the youths have usually
taken their medications and are in bed.
Staff G
Staff G reported working a split shift, whereby by she works two first shift days, one
second shift day, and two third shift days. She reported three or four weeks prior to
this interview the agency did not have a first shift (7:00am-3:00pm) staff person on
Wednesday and Saturday. Therefore, second or third shift staff were responsible for
having the youth to come take their medication. She said during second shift there
were multiple occasions, (she clarified that to be at least three times) she knocked
on Youth 1’s door to have Youth 1 come get her medication; and Youth 1 did not.
Youth 1 had later reported she heard Staff G but did not answer. Therefore, on those
occasions, Youth 1 did not get her AM medications. Staff G said Youth 1 was
recently given the okay to keep her medication in her room. Staff G said prior to that
she had started getting Youth 1’s AM medication to hold, so that when Youth 1 came
to get Youth 1’s PM medication, she also gave her the AM to take later. Staff G
agreed it was true the documentation that the medication was handed out may not
be there in the log. She advised that was because after she knocked on Youth 1’s
door and did not get an answer, she left the job and went home because it was the
end of her shift. Staff G did not know if the third shift worker, Staff F had
experienced similar behavior with Youth 1 related to getting the medication to Youth
1.
Reviewed:
Youth 1’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• Youth 1 is a temporary court ward.
• She had an intake interview and was placed at Samaritas IL home on
5/13/2022.
• Youth 1’s intake package, inclusive of an initial assessment, initial
budget, IL plus plan and IL contracts and proof Youth 1 received a
copy of the agency’s IL handbook and medication agreement.
The agency ‘s Medication Agreement which indicated:
• “For many youth in Independent Living Plus, medications are an important
component of their independent living plan.
• Some youth enter the program with medications prescribed by a previous
physician. Some youth are prescribed medications after they enter the
7

program. Either way, it is essential that medications are managed by a
physician, taken exactly as prescribed and disposed of properly.
• If you have any concerns regarding your medications, you need to
address them with the prescribing physician. You may not begin, stop, or
alter the dosage of any medication that is prescribed by a physician
without consulting with the prescribing physician and informing the IL Plus
Coordinator of the change.
• As a youth participating in the Independent Living Plus Program with
Samaritas, I agree to cooperate with the case plan which includes the
administration, monitoring and proper disposal (in consultation with a
pharmacist), of all medications for me. I agree to discuss any questions
and/or concerns regarding my medication with my physician and
caseworker. At no time, will I begin, stop, or alter the dosage of any
medication or prevent its use without written documentation from the
monitoring physician. Any written documentation shall be shared with the
Agency.”
The medical agreement does not indicate anything related to the agency locking,
storing or administering a youth’s medication.
The staff’s daily log for third shift entries from 5/15/2022 until 7/1/2022(the day after this
complaint. The log entries showed:
• Numerous entries did not report information on medication; nor whether or not
Youth 1 took her medication. One entry indicated the staff knocked on Youth 1’s
door and there was no answer.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(1) An agency shall have and follow a current written
program statement that includes all of the following
information:
(g) medical and dental care.
8

ANALYSIS: Youth 1 was not consistently provided her GERD medication
twice daily as required. All staff interviewed reported it is the
agency’s rule and or protocol to keep all youth medications
locked up, which the third shift staff provides to the youth. The
agency’s policy does not indicate these protocols.
Additionally, there is not a clear or consistent system in place to
accurately illustrate that a youth is capable of administrating
their medication. Nor how medication administration/ assistance
is documented. Staff D a second shift IL worker reported the
administration of Youth 1’s medication was to be documented
by the third shift IL worker in the staff’s daily log. Conversely
Staff F, the third shift IL worker reported she would only provide
the youth’s medication if the second shift IL worker informed her
they had not. A review of the staff’ daily log had inconsistent
documentation about medication administration and did not
show/define what specific medication was given or handed to
the youth.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
(1) Youth 1 has allergies and GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease) and is not
being provided appropriate foods needed for her diet.
(2) Youth 1 did not come to the agency with a medical passport and the agency did
not seek one to know and ensure Youth 1’s dietary needs are met.
(3) The agency has not timely assisted Youth 1 in obtaining food stamps/a bridge
card.
INVESTIGATION:
Complainant X
On 6/30/2022 I spoke with Complainant X about the allegation by telephone.
Complainant X reported Youth 1 is not being fed the special diet of foods Youth 1
needs for her digestive disorder GERD. Complainant X did not clarify what those
foods are but reported Youth 1 reported her foods are mixed with the other youths
and she does not get what she needs. The other youths will consume it all and the
agency does not buy enough. The agency only purchases $100-$150 in groceries
every two weeks. Youth 1 does not have any way to go buy her food. Youth 1’s
mother provides Youth 1 with Door Dash food gift cards to assist Youth 1 with buying
food.
Complainant X also reported via a written complaint document that: Youth 1 went to
the IL home on 5/13/2022; and the agency did not obtain a copy of Youth 1’s medical
passport to know Youth 1’s GERD and allergy needs. Nor has Youth 1’s food stamps
come through timely. Complainant X acknowledged she does not know the reason
why Youth 1’s food stamps were delayed, only that the agency has not made
9

arrangements to get Youth 1 the adequate food Youth 1 needs.
Independent Living Director B
On 7/5/2022, and 7/18/2022 I spoke with Independent Living (IL) Director B by
telephone. He also provided information to me via email on 7/7/2022. IL Director B
reported the agency orders food for the youths every two weeks, and as needed
should issues come up. He advised this is an independent living program. All the
girls in this IL home have bridge cards which they can purchase food with. Case
Manager E assists all the girls in applying for a bridge care when they first arrive at the
home. Additionally, all the girls receive a monetary monthly stipend, which they use for
their needs. He reported the agency personally pays for one meal per day, and one
meat per week for the youths. Their second shift IL worker, Staff D is the person who
works with youths (Which as of 7/5/2022 consisted of Youth 1 and three other youths)
around the grocery orders. Staff D will ask each youth for food items they want or feel
they need.
On 7/7/2022, IL Director B provided four grocery receipts (dated 5/13/2022, 5/26/2022,
6/15/2022 and 7/1/2022) that were orders since Youth 1’s placement. The receipts
showed food purchases and items connected to Youth 1 GERD and allergy needs, such
as almond milk, fruits, meats (chicken, ground beef), noodles, cereal. He said Youth 3
also has GERD and food items are purchased for both of these youths.
IL Director B further reported that after it came to his attention, maybe via this
complaint, that someone was reportedly taking Youth 1’s specific dietary foods, he
advised Youth 1 he would purchase her a mini refrigerator for her room. He
subsequently did so. He advised that the kitchen refrigerator is a community one for the
house/all youths; and staff cannot guard it all the time. IL Director B reported Youth 1
“is not malnourished”, her food needs are met.
IL Director B reported Youth 1’s dietary issues, restrictions were discussed during her
placement intake; and they are in her records, inclusive of a past medical passports,
which became accessible to the agency. He reported Case Manager E assists all youth
in obtaining a bridge card and did so for Youth 1.
Youth 1
Youth 1 was interviewed onsite at the IL home on 7/6/2022. Youth 1 reported the
special diet she is on due to her GERD is that “I cannot eat paste like foods, certain
sauces or acidic foods and drinks”. She said she is also lactose intolerant; and she
must eat foods high in fiber. Youth 1 reported she just received her bridge card; and
before that she had no way to buy her food. She admitted the agency buys almond milk
and other foods for her special diet. The problem is that Youth 3 who also has GERD,
many times was using up all the food; and the staff said they could not control what the
other girls were taking from the refrigerator. Youth 1 reported the agency should have
bought more food than they had, and there would not have been a problem.
10

Youth 1 admitted to being involved in the ordering of food; that she and other youths
meet with Staff D around a grocery list, and Staff D orders the food. She added that
what Staff D orders, at times depends on what youth Staff D listens to. I asked Youth 1
what food she had asked for which were ordered, and she stated, almond milk, noodles
for pasta salad, fruit (melon and strawberries). She could not identify any specific foods
that had not been purchased for her. She added that all the meals the group plans, she
cannot eat such as pizza and Mexican food. She said there is food in the house, but she
refuses to eat it. She asked her mother for door dash cash so she can get the foods she
wants.
Youth 1 reported the agency told her about the process for how to apply for a food
assistance bridge card. She said the agency assisted her in applying for one on her
first day at the IL home. She reported, however, Case Manager E never told her how
long the process would take. She reported receiving her EBT ((Electronic Benefit
Transfer) card one to two weeks prior to my interview with her.
Youth 2 and Youth 3
Youth 2 and Youth 3 were interviewed by me onsite at the IL home on 7/6/2022. Neither
youth knew specifics related to Youth 1’s special diet/ needs. They reported general
information related to the IL home’s food shopping/purchasing, and the process they
experienced with getting a bridge card.
Youth 2 reported being unsure of how often food is purchased for the home but
admitted to having a bridge card to purchase food. She said she applied for the bridge
card on her own with assistance from Youth 1, not Case Manager E. She affirmed
Youth 1’s reporting of the youths getting together to decide what to order; and Staff D
ordering the food. She said Staff D is the main person working to get them what they
need.
Youth 3 said the agency orders food every two-three weeks and they have their EBT
cards. The latter of which Case Manager E helped her apply for. She said getting
approved for the bridge card took about one to two weeks. She reported not being on a
special diet. She said she just cannot have milk, oranges or strawberries. She affirmed
that for groceries they talk about what they want as a group. Staff D then gets pretty
much what they asked for. Youth 3 said the food is gone in about a week and the staff
calls Case Manager E and reports that. She said they also have their bridge card to
use for food, but the problem is the neighborhood is not so safe; and getting to the
store.
Staff C, Staff F and Staff G
Staff C was interviewed by me about this allegation onsite on 7/6/2022. Staff F was
interviewed by me via telephone on 7/21/2022; and Staff G by me onsite on 7/28/2022.
All three IL workers reported not being involved in food ordering. Staff G reported
knowing that Staff D is responsible for ordering groceries, which is delivered to the
home; and that Staff D asks each youth for items they want her to purchase. Staff G
11

was aware of items, like almond milk, and lactose type cheese being purchased for
Youth 1 and Youth 3.
Staff C, Staff F nor Staff G had information related to the allegations pertaining to Youth
1’s medical passport and bridge card application.
Staff D
Staff D was interviewed by me onsite on 7/6/2022. She affirmed information reported by
others related to her getting the residents together to discuss the grocery list, and her
ordering or arranging the ordering of food. She reported an awareness of Youth 1 and
Youth 3’s dietary needs due to their lactose intolerance and special food issues. She
tries to get enough food for both within the IL house’s budget. She advised they spend
$150.00- $250.00 every two weeks depending on the number of girls in the home at the
time (when only one youth is in the home they have ordered food every three weeks)
The foods they purchase is in providing the agency’s one meal a day (usually dinner)
and sides. There is never a time that there is no food in the home, but it may be that it is
foods the girls do not want; and the girls do complaint about it. When that occurs, Staff
D tries to work with the girls on preparation of dishes with the items that are there. The
youths cook their own food. Staff D assists the girls with food preparation when the girls
have struggles cooking. Staff D said when the food gets low she reaches out to Case
Manager E and or IL Director B to request to order more food. The request approval
happens within two to three days. The girls also have their bridge cards to purchase
food. When she orders food, Youth 1 asks for and is provided items such as almond
milk, fruits, noodles, and ingredients to make her own paste sauce. Staff D admitted
there had been a time when Youth 3 utilized the bulk of the smaller carton of almond
milk, even those it was labeled for Youth 1. Staff D reported the items were in the
kitchen refrigerator which is hard to regulate against access. Staff D tried to remedy that
problem by increasing the size of the milk.
Staff D was not aware anything to do with Youth 1’s medical passport issue or Youth 1
having a problem getting her EBT card. Staff D reported knowing that sometimes the
food stamp process is delayed due to the state.
Case Manager E
Case Manager E was interviewed about these allegations by me via telephone on
7/13/2022. Case Manager E reported information similar to IL Director B and Staff D
related to grocery ordering timeframes, spending totals, and Staff D’s role/responsibility
related to grocery shopping and interaction with the youths around that. Case Manager
E reported Youth 1 has participated in the discussions with Staff D on food orders. She
said dietary items of food is purchased for Youth 1. She reported Youth 1 will often say
there is no food at the IL home; though, there is chicken, spaghetti or special cheese
and milk Youth 1 requested. She said, Youth 1 will also say she is hunger but will not
eat the food onsite; or Youth 1 will decide to eat a peanut butter sandwich. She said
Youth 1 will request food cards from Youth 1’s mother, so Youth 1 can order fast foods
Youth 1 wants at a given time; not because there is not food in the home.
12

Case Manager E reported Youth 1’s medical passport was not included in the referral
package as is usually the case with a referral package. She reported participating in the
placement intake for Youth 1. She recalled the Family Community Service agency
where Youth 1 was coming from advocating for Youth 1. That agency informed her of
Youth 1’s GERD diagnosis, lactose intolerance and medications needs and issues. One
of, the GERD medication, Zyrtec was over the counter at that time and remained so,
